title: Mithril
data:
**Mithril** is a [material](/wiki/Material "Material") for items that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*.

Mithril is a lightweight metal used in [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor") for [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") and [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)") to produce [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor"). It is immune to [erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion"), but will hinder [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 Origin](#Origin)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.4 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [4.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [5 Encyclopaedia entry](#Encyclopaedia_entry)

## Description

There are three items made of mithril:

- [dwarvish mithril-coat](/wiki/Dwarvish_mithril-coat "Dwarvish mithril-coat")
- [elven mithril-coat](/wiki/Elven_mithril-coat "Elven mithril-coat")
- [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor")

[Metallivores](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore") such as [rock moles](/wiki/Rock_mole "Rock mole") and [xorns](/wiki/Xorn "Xorn") can eat any item made of mithril, save for the Amulet.

## Strategy

Dwarvish and elven mithril-coats are the lightest such suits of body armor for the protection they provide (6 and 5 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC"), respectively, along with [MC3](/wiki/MC3 "MC3")).

The Amulet of Yendor's material prevents it from being damaged or destroyed, but has no other noticeable effects.

## Origin

Mithril is a material derived from the Middle-earth setting created by [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien").

## Variants

Some variants add new items made of mithril, and variants that implement an [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") system also make it possible for certain metallic items to be made of mithril.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the [dark elven mithril-coat](/wiki/Dark_elven_mithril-coat "Dark elven mithril-coat") is a suit of body armor made from the material, and is functionally identical to a dwarvish mithril-coat.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), [chunks of raw mithril ore](/wiki/Small_piece_of_unrefined_mithril "Small piece of unrefined mithril") can be found buried on the first level of the [Ruins of Moria](/wiki/Ruins_of_Moria "Ruins of Moria"), but due to being unrefined they are considered stones (and thus made of [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral")) rather than actual mithril. Their only purpose is to be sold at [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), where they are priced at more than twice the value of a [dilithium crystal](/wiki/Dilithium_crystal "Dilithium crystal").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), mithril weighs half as much as iron. High-elven armor and weapons use mithril as their base [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(dNetHack\) "Object materials (dNetHack)").

Some artifacts are made of mithril:

- [Soulmirror](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Soulmirror "DNetHack artifacts") (neutral mithril [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail"))
- [The Web of Lolth](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Web_of_Lolth "DNetHack artifacts") (chaotic silvered elven mithril-coat)
- [The Armor of Khazad-dum](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Armor_of_Khazad-dum "DNetHack artifacts") (lawful dwarvish mithril-coat)
- It is possible to create a mithril [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") by [dipping](/wiki/Dipping "Dipping") a mithril [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"), though these are usually difficult to find.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), mithril body armor always grants at least MC2.

Dwarvish and elven mithril-coats are replaced by [racial ring mail](/wiki/Racial_equipment "Racial equipment") - a dwarvish or elven ring mail made of mithril thus acts identically to a mithril-coat. Hobbits that are given an elven ring mail will always get a mithril set; dwarf lords and kings that get dwarvish ring mail have an increased chance of it being mithril.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), mithril gives a +2 damage bonus to slashing and piercing weapons, and is among one of the better materials for armor in particular. Mithril is inherently fixed, but is still subject to decay via the [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") [destroy armor](/wiki/Destroy_armor_\(monster_spell\) "Destroy armor (monster spell)").

Elves wearing mithril body armor are granted MC3, compared to MC2 for all other races. [Orcish monsters](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)") are mithril-hating and take extra damage from mithril weapons: orcs wielding or wearing any mithril that make skin contact take damage from that action, and their [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") regeneration is suppressed until the item is unwielded or taken off. Wielding such an item without [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves") will also result in a -1 [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") penalty.

Most objects with a base material of iron, steel, or wood have a low chance of being randomly generated as mithril, including non-cloth armor and weapons of dwarvish and elven make. Horns, most bows and [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection")-granting objects also have a slightly higher chance of generating as mithril, and [staves of matter](/index.php?title=Staff_of_matter\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Staff of matter (page does not exist)") use mithril as their base material. The [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") [Dirge](/wiki/Dirge "Dirge") is a mithril long sword.

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM changes, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") features the mithril ring as a randomized ring appearance made of mithril.

## Encyclopaedia entry

\_Mithril\_! All folk desired it. It could be beaten like  
copper, and polished like glass; and the Dwarves could make  
of it a metal, light and yet harder than tempered steel.  
Its beauty was like to that of common silver, but the beauty  
of \_mithril\_ did not tarnish or grow dim.

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]
